item.title: Open-World Games With The Most Creative Ways To Kill Enemies
item.description:
Summary

  • Creative kills in open-world games can be highly rewarding for players.
  • Titles like Just Cause 3 and Cyberpunk 2077 allow for unique combat strategies.
  • Games like Hogwarts Legacy offer special spell combinations for player creativity.

Countless gamers love the idea of going ballistic in most open-world games. There's a reason why games with massive sandboxes are so popular; the inherent freedom players have to tackle the world and its challenges in whatever manner they see fit is often incredibly rewarding.

Since these games usually come equipped with some form of combat, the majority of gamers tend to appreciate it when these battles and firefights allow them to get creative with their kills and cut down anyone and anything in style. For gamers looking to get creative with how they approach taking down their enemies, here are some of the best open-world games to check out.

Just Cause 3

Some Fatal Explosions Can Be Triggered In Very Creative Ways

Just Cause 3
8 /10
8.0 /10
Released
November 30, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Blood, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Powered by

The mod for Just Cause 2 that allowed Rico to attach his grappling hook to more than one tether ended up being one of the best ways to manipulate the game's physics for hilarious results. So, many fans were glad to see that the developers were inspired by this mod, turning this multi-tether mechanic into a feature in the sequel.

Countless players love wreaking havoc as Rico in Just Cause 3 , using his grappling hook to make enemies flail around helplessly. Given the title's focus on explosive gameplay, players are also free to try something unique and use a combination of their firepower and the grappling hook to make enemies pay.

Far Cry 5

The Most Satisfying Kills In The Game Are The Ones That Require A Ton Of Creativity

Far Cry 5
9 /10
21
7.8 /10
Released
March 27, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Powered by

The improvements made to the Far Cry formula in the fifth mainline entry were minor yet quite impactful, allowing players to enjoy one of the fresher games in the series. On top of that, Far Cry 5 also boasts a compelling combat system that has only become more satisfying to play with over time.

Improving the deputy's skills and figuring out the best way to take out everyone in an outpost from the shadows makes for a great time. Even if players are spotted, they'll have a ton of firepower and their trusted companions to rely on for some creative carnage as they obliterate everything in sight.

Hogwarts Legacy

Some Spell Combinations Can Be Especially Satisfying To Land

Hogwarts Legacy
9 /10
75
8.7 /10
Released
February 10, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Fantasy Violence, Mild Language, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

While Hogwarts Legacy has its fair share of issues, most people agree that the game's combat is in a class of its own. Many players love just how much fun it can be to take on groups of enemies once the fifth-year student begins to unlock some of the more powerful spells.

Players can combo the Unforgivable Curses, allowing them to turn enemies over to their side, and mark them with a Curse, so that an Avada Kedavra takes out multiple foes in one fell swoop. Along with this, Diffindo-ing frozen enemies and pulling foes with Accio before blasting them with Incendio are just a few of the many ways players can get creative with their spellcasting in the game.

Ghost Of Tsushima

As Jin's Options In Combat Increase, So Do The Creative Options Afforded To Players

Ghost of Tsushima
9 /10
43
8.9 /10
Released
July 17, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language, Partial Nudity
Powered by

Ghost of Tsushima is one of the most beautiful open-world games ever made. One of the best parts of this game is the tantalizing mix of combat and stealth, giving players a ton of options to rely on as they take on waves of Mongols and other enemies.

Going in for an honorable face-off against enemies is great in its own right, with players having several tools to rely on for crowd control. Stealth also allows players to get creative with their kills, especially when they get darts that cause enemies to go berserk and turn on their allies.

Grand Theft Auto 5

Some Of The Weapons In The Game Are A Blast To Experiment With

5 Images
5 Images
Grand Theft Auto 5
9 /10
148
8.9 /10
Released
September 17, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Mature Humor, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Powered by

The Grand Theft Auto series is known for featuring wanton chaos and destruction, and the fifth mainline entry is no exception here. As players make progress in the story, they'll slowly unlock a wealth of powerful guns in Ammu-Nation that will allow them to go ballistic on their foes.

Setting up traps using sticky bombs, overpowering enemies with fully automatic weaponry, and using both Michael's and Trevor's abilities in firefights makes for some engaging ways to take on enemies. Players can get creative with the vehicles they bring into combat, too, running over a few enemies to thin the herd before getting out and going into cover.

Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain

The Malleability Of The Fox Engine Allows For Some Creative Takedowns And Kills

Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain
9 /10
8.6 /10
Released
September 1, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language
Powered by

The Phantom Pain served as an impressive showing of the Fox Engine and everything it brings to the table. Many players loved the amazing graphics and general feel of this title, but it was the combat and stealth options that really wowed the majority.

Snake can employ everything from decoys to the classic cardboard box to help him sneak around outposts. Enemies can also be taken out in creative ways, with a notable example involving players requesting a crate drop on a foe's head in order to knock them out and acquire some valuable equipment in one fell swoop.

Cyberpunk 2077

Players Can Become A Blur Of Destruction In Combat As They Use Every Tool In Their Arsenal

6 Images
6 Images
Cyberpunk 2077
6 /10
112
8.9 /10
Released
December 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Powered by

Cyberpunk 2077 's gameplay has improved by leaps and bounds since its release. With Update 2.0, players won't be able to load themselves up on cyberware until they gain enough levels so that their body can handle it.

Eventually, at high levels, V will have a ridiculous number of options to choose from in combat. Lunging at enemies with a katana, using Berserk to nail powerful superhero landings that hurt, and using Quickhacks to gain an advantage in a fight are just a few of the many ways that V can get creative while dealing with their foes in Cyberpunk 2077 .

Elden Ring

Experimenting With The Tarnished's Build Can Let Players Use The Game's Most Creative Setups

6 Images
6 Images
Elden Ring
10 /10
68
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

FromSoftware's most successful title features their patented gameplay loop, full of the many quirks and oddities that fans would expect from the developer. Beginners are better off getting a grasp of the basics before trying to understand how to deal with tougher enemies in Elden Ring .

However, those who become more adept at playing the game can employ experimental builds and use a variety of unique abilities to make combat more engaging than ever. For a game that can be super hard to deal with at times, employing these creative moves to defeat enemies in style never gets old.

item.title: Most Underrated PlayStation Games Ever, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Underrated PlayStation games like Days Gone offer unique experiences despite initial issues around their releases.
  • Sackboy: A Big Adventure is a creative platformer often overlooked due to audience preferences.
  • Gravity Rush 2 stands out for its imaginative traversal and combat, deserving much more recognition.

The PlayStation brand is extremely strong, and even some uncharacteristic missteps during this generation haven't stopped Sony from making major waves in the industry. The PS5 has sold a ton of units and is full of quality titles, even if the lack of first-party releases is something that irritates fans.

Throughout its legendary run in the video game industry, there are some PlayStation games with creative gameplay loops and other engaging elements that have not received the success or accolades they deserve. It's a shame, but fans can always give these titles a shot to see why they're some of the most underrated titles to ever release on a PlayStation console.

8 Days Gone

After a Rough Initial Launch, Fans Slowly Warmed Up to this Title

Days Gone
8 /10
37
9.1 /10
Released
April 26, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Bend Studio
Publisher(s)
Sony
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Days Gone is the poster child of an underrated PlayStation game. The technical issues upon launch, coupled with a slow beginning and a rather unlikable protagonist, all contributed to this title's middling reviews.

Eventually, after the bugs and glitches were fixed, more and more players have come around to appreciate this title's muted brilliance. It has its issues, but Days Gone does enough unique things to stand out and is one of the most underrated PlayStation games that zombie/open world fans should definitely check out.

7 Sackboy: A Big Adventure

An Underrated Platformer that Deserves More Eyes on it

Sackboy: A Big Adventure
8 /10
7.5 /10
Released
November 12, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Sumo Digital
Publisher(s)
Sony
Platform(s)
PS4, PS5, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

It's a shame that the PlayStation's audience isn't too keen on platformers. As a result, genuinely creative games like Sackboy: A Big Adventure end up getting lost in the shuffle as more mature games dominate the mainstream instead.

Sackboy 's imaginative levels are great to overcome, especially with this cute eponymous character at the helm. Unfortunately, the Sackboy brand failed to make a major impression, and this character was phased out in favor of Astro Bot as the PlayStation's mascot.

6 PaRappa the Rapper

A Charming Rhythm Game that Fans Love

PaRappa the Rapper
Rhythm
Systems
Released
September 26, 1997

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Publisher(s)
Sony Computer Entertainment
Platform(s)
PS1, PSP
Powered by

For a rhythm game, it's amazing just how fun PaRappa the Rapper is. The tunes are genuinely catchy and will keep players invested, even if this title can be ridiculously hard and unforgiving with its timings.

Thankfully, the timeless visuals and inherent charm of this title will make it easy to power through the many failures to eventually pass a stage. This helps PaRappa the Rapper shine, and it's a shame that this character didn't get more time in the spotlight as Sony's strategy for the PlayStation evolved to cater to a mature audience.

5 Ico

Team Ico's Least-Known Title that Set the Foundation for Their Creative and Charming Games

Ico
10.0 /10
Released
September 24, 2001

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
JapanStudio, Team Ico
Publisher(s)
Sony Computer Entertainment
Platform(s)
PS2
Powered by

The very name of the studio (Team Ico) should make it clear just how important their first game was. This subsidiary of Japan Studio crafted an amazing and beautiful game that somehow turned a prolonged escort mission into a riveting experience.

Ico 's beauty is what inspired both Shadow of the Colossus and The Last Guardian . So, it's a shame that this title has seemingly been forgotten, while its other games have received either modern releases or remakes to attract more fans.

4 The Order: 1886

On Sale, Fans Will Appreciate this Atmospheric Game Despite its Short Length

The Order: 1886
7 /10
6.0 /10
Released
February 20, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Ready at Dawn
Publisher(s)
Sony
Platform(s)
PS4
Powered by

When The Order: 1886 came out, most fans couldn't help but deride the game's short lengths and its archaic QTE system. This made it hard to justify the game's price tag, turning The Order: 1886 into an early PS4 failure that never managed to make a comeback.

Now, with this title being available for peanuts, fans have slowly come to appreciate the title's brilliance and potential. Even now, the visuals look amazing, and the crunchy third-person shooting gameplay will keep fans engaged for its short yet entertaining runtime.

3 Gravity Rush 2

One of the Most Unique Video Games Fans Can Check Out

Gravity Rush 2
8 /10
7.0 /10
Released
January 20, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
JapanStudio
Publisher(s)
Sony
Platform(s)
PlayStation 4
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Players who think that Marvel's Spider-Man 2 is the best superhero game on the PlayStation with a great sense of traversal have clearly not tried both Gravity Rush and its sequel. Most people find Gravity Rush 2 to be one of the most underrated games associated with the PlayStation brand.

It shone on the PS Vita and eventually received a port to the PlayStation 4, but while it amassed a passionate fanbase, Gravity Rush 2 never quite pulled in enough interest to garner additional games in the series (yet, at any rate). Gravity Rush 2 deserves more attention for its imaginative take on traversal, world design, and combat, all of which enhance the game's unique allure.

2 Tokyo Jungle

A Bizarre Yet Charming Title that Players Will Have a Great Time With

Tokyo Jungle
Survival
Systems
Released
September 25, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Crispy's!
Publisher(s)
Sony Computer Entertainment
Platform(s)
PS3, PS Vita
Powered by

Tokyo Jungle is one of the most bizarre PlayStation video games, which is perhaps why many people haven't checked out this unique title. Players control various kinds of animals in a version of Tokyo ruined by a mysterious apocalypse that led to humanity's demise.

It's an interesting premise, with the hilarious gameplay seeing players controlling either herbivores or carnivores as they struggle to survive in this overgrown world. Players who love animals and want to check out one of the weirdest and most engrossing PlayStation games ever made need to give Tokyo Jungle a shot.

1 Heavenly Sword

Despite its Short Length, Nariko's Action-Packed Adventures Are Quite Riveting

Heavenly Sword
Hack and Slash
Systems
Released
September 12, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Ninja Theory
Publisher(s)
Sony Computer Entertainment
Platform(s)
PS3
Powered by

In an age when video games try to integrate as many gameplay systems as possible to keep fans engaged, Heavenly Sword 's simplicity will serve as a breath of fresh air. Players control the fated warrior Nariko, who fights against the heinous forces of King Botan.

The stylish combat of Heavenly Sword , coupled with Andy Serkis' stand-out performance as King Botan, will make for a great experience that doesn't overstay its welcome. It may be more challenging to play Heavenly Sword nowadays, but players who get their hands on a copy of this game will have a great time with this hack-and-slash title.

item.title: Grow a Garden: All Crops (& How to Get Them)
item.description:
Crops are the main way to earn money in the Roblox game Grow a Garden . From juicy fruits to fresh veggies, you’ll find plenty of options to raise in this gardening sim. But first, you’ll need to get the seeds. Once planted, crops take real-time hours to grow before you can harvest them.

Some crops grow back and give you multiple harvests, while others are one-time use. Either way, they turn your garden into a fun farming spot that you can enjoy solo or with friends. Here's a look at every crop available in Grow a Garden , how to get them, and which ones are best for making money fast.

Updated on August 3, 2025, by Somiya Adrees: This guide now shows the latest ways to snag seeds in Grow a Garden. The full crop list now includes the current prices of all plants up to the 1.17.0 update (and, of course, where to buy them). Along with that, you'll also find the number of fruits each one of those crops blesses you, so you can easily pick the most profitable Multi-Harvest ones. The best crops section has been refreshed to match what’s good in GaG right now.

How to Get Crop Seeds in Grow a Garden

While the game often hosts special events like Blood Moon and Bee Swarm that offer limited-time seeds, there are four ways to get permanent ones in Grow a Garden . Here’s a quick breakdown of each method:

Sam's Seed Shop

This is one of the easiest ways to get crop seeds. You’ll spot the Seed Shop next to the Sell Stall, or you can access it by clicking the "Seed" button at the top of your screen. Seeds here cost in-game currency called Sheckles or even Robux. However, not all seeds are available at all times. To get your favorite ones, you might need to wait for a restock, which usually happens every five minutes.

Gear Shop Quests

You can earn seeds by completing daily quests from Eloise. He's the same NPC who sells tools at the Gear Shop . Finish all three daily quests to receive Seed Packs, which contain random crop seeds of various rarities.

Seed Pets

Grow a Garden ’s Update 1.04.0 added pets to make things more fun. Some, like the Golden Lab, Dog, and Red Fox, can get you free seeds just by walking around your garden or your neighbors’. So, when you’re trying to farm seeds, place three or more pets that can do that.

Super Seed

The Super Seed is a premium item that gives you a secret crop seed. It’s only accessible with real money and typically appears in the Forever Pack section of the game shop. That section doesn’t appear often, so grab the seed whenever it pops up.

Seed Crafting Tables

You can also create seeds at the Seed Crafting Table by submitting the required ingredients, such as Honey, plants, and seed packs. There are several profitable crop seeds you can make there. If you’re curious about how crafting works, this guide will walk you through it. Just so you know, the crafting table has been merged with the Cosmetics stall now, so you can access it from there.

Exotic Seed Pack

Lastly, players can grab seeds (especially exclusive ones) by purchasing the Exotic Seed Pack with Robux. It’s a paid item and doesn’t show up all the time, so grab it when you see it in the game shop.

All Crops in Grow a Garden

All Crops

Complete the Dino Quests to earn the Bone Blossom Seed as a weekly prize

No

Mutations play a big role in raising crop prices. For example, a Shocked Cactus can go for as much as 700,000 Sheckles, way more than a regular Cactus. Fruits from traveling merchants may cost more or less than their listed price.

Best Crop Seeds in Grow a Garden

A few of the best crops in Grow a Garden include Bone Blossom and Candy Blossom ; each can give you a single fruit worth 100k Sheckles or more. Other great picks are Maple Apple, Spiked Mango, Dragon Pepper, Fossilight Fruit and Moon Mango.

If you're after permanent crops that stick around throughout the game, go for Giant Pinecone, Sugar Apple, Beanstalk and Elder Strawberry . These are all reharvestable; once fully grown, they keep producing fruit every few minutes, making them perfect for steady income.

For one-time harvests, Parasol Flowers, Bendboos, and Mushrooms are solid picks. But compared to them, Sunflowers, Ember Lilies, and Honeysuckles are even better since they also grow one at a time but can be harvested more than once.

If you want to learn more about the top-earning plants in GaG , our Best Crops Tier List can help you out.

item.title: Best Open-World Games With Endless Replayability
item.description:
Summary

  • RPG elements, freedom, vast maps, hours of narrative, and procedural generation contribute to the replay value of open-world games.
  • Titles like Skyrim , Elden Ring , Cyberpunk 2077 , Kenshi , and Fallout: New Vegas offer deep customization and roleplay for players.
  • Minecraft and No Man's Sky offer endless playability in a sandbox, procedural environment.

By definition, open-world games are some of the longest single-player titles available today, often providing vast explorable maps coupled with hours of story-driven narrative. While almost every open-world game offers enough content to keep players occupied for dozens of hours, some games stretch even further, offering near-endless replayability .

More often than not, such potential stems from the RPG nature of many open-world games, filled with non-linear story paths and side quests with plenty of branching choices, but it's not just that. Some open-world games are known for their unrestricted freedom or even procedural generation techniques that can keep players occupied and surprise them each time they start a new playthrough.

Below are some of the best open-world games that provide great replay value , either through deep customization and roleplay options, robust potential for non-linear story and quest choices, sandbox environments, crafting mechanics, or procedural generation of the world.

The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Beloved Setting Players Are Willing To Live In

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
9 /10
80
9.5 /10
Released
November 11, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

Over the years, Skyrim has more than earned its reputation as one of the most beloved and replayable open-world RPGs by Bethesda, which is an achievement in itself. Even newer and more ambitious games by the developer, like Fallout 4 and Starfield , have failed to match Skyrim 's lasting legacy for a variety of reasons, including its list of available platforms.

With Skyrim , the team managed to capture an alluring sense of discovery and freedom, which, coupled with its unmistakable atmosphere and unique setting, has really grown on players. Packed with content, characters, quests, factions, and missable locations, Skyrim allows players to play as they want to, each time experiencing the world anew. Even without its thriving modding community, vanilla Skyrim remains a go-to game for many open-world RPG enthusiasts and newcomers to the genre, and its enduring popularity shows no signs of stopping.

Elden Ring

Enormous Scope And Cryptic Nature Leave Many Mysteries Unanswered

Elden Ring
10 /10
68
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Less a narrative-driven, quest-based RPG and more an exploration-based action game, Elden Ring is a definitive choice for players looking for unparalleled combat build variety and an abundance of unique enemies to find and test their battle skills against. Thanks to its twisted, vertical, vast map with countless hidden areas and locations, as well as its cryptic nature for side quests, NPCs, and overall progression, some fans can beat the game and see just a tiny fraction of what it has to offer.

From its near-endless array of weapons, armor, and talismans to over 200 total bosses to defeat, Elden Ring is at its best when players go in blind, slowly uncovering more of the game with each subsequent playthrough, gradually gaining access to previously missed areas, overlooked enemies, questlines, and endings.

Fallout: New Vegas

One Of The Most Flexible Open-Worlds For Roleplay

Fallout: New Vegas
8 /10
22
8.9 /10
Released
October 19, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Powered by

While Fallout 4 offers more sheer freedom and variety in gameplay thanks to its robust crafting mechanics that allow players to shape the wasteland to their liking, Fallout: New Vegas remains the pinnacle for engaging roleplay in the series. With unparalleled freedom when it comes to quest solving, including rich dialogue choices and the ability to use skills in unconventional ways, New Vegas truly shines for RPG enthusiasts interested in experiencing this universe in unlikely ways.

A large part of Fallout: New Vegas is the game's four major factions (like NCR or Legion) that players can join during their playthrough, unlocking access to new questlines, unpredictable consequences, and deep interactions with entirely different NPCs. Even after almost fifteen years, few open-world RPGs can match the scope of roleplay potential that Obsidian achieved here.

Cyberpunk 2077

A Perfect Blend Of Cinematic Storytelling With Plenty Of Choice

Cyberpunk 2077
6 /10
112
8.9 /10
Released
December 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Powered by

Following in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt 's footsteps, already a cornerstone of the open-world RPG genre, Cyberpunk 2077 doubled down on some important aspects, providing even greater replay value for RPG fans. Not only does Cyberpunk 2077 feature a robust character creator and three different prologues, unlike The Witcher 3 , but the game generally offers more choices in dialogue and quests for players to experience Night City in vastly different ways with each new run.

Almost every one of the game's 300 quests can be tackled in different ways, depending on players' vision for the protagonist V, their gender, relationships with other characters, as well as gameplay preferences for combat, hacking, or stealth. Cyberpunk 2077 also benefits greatly from CDPR's dedicated support, with new content updates bringing additional features even now, almost five years after launch.

Kenshi

Lack Of A Traditional Narrative Turned Into A Benefit

Kenshi
10.0 /10
Released
December 6, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
nr
Powered by

Kenshi is a different breed of seamless open-world RPG, without a traditional linear main narrative. Instead, players create their character and emerge into a free-roaming sandbox survival environment where they can become anyone. In a way, playing Kenshi is like receiving one life each time to survive this unforgiving, ever-changing world by all means necessary.

It's worth noting that Kenshi 's open world is one of the biggest ever, stretching over 870 square kilometers, never restricting players' goals but not revolving around the player either. A large focus of Kenshi is on players' squads, as they can create not one but several characters, each with their own traits, evolving over time and gaining more experience. Building, exploring, crafting, trading, and fighting – anything is possible in Kenshi , and thanks to its dynamic nature, this gem shouldn't be overlooked.

Minecraft

More Like A Space For Endless Playability

Minecraft
191
9.0 /10
Released
November 18, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Powered by

A truly ever-lasting open-world sandbox, Minecraft isn't really a title players are meant to “beat,” so in this case, it's more about endless playability available from the get-go and pushed further with each new update. Players are free to explore one of the largest open worlds ever put into a video game, surviving, fighting, gathering, and building whatever and however they want. The unprecedented crafting possibilities grant Minecraft unmatched depth, as players can literally play it forever, limited only by their imagination.

Alternatively, the 2D open-world experience Terraria is another example of a flexible playground where players can build, explore, discover, and have fun nearly endlessly. Like Minecraft , Terraria is also elevated by procedural generation techniques for creating its sandbox world for each player.

No Man's Sky

Unrestricted Procedural Universe Brimming With Possibilities

No Man's Sky
7 /10
61
9.3 /10
Released
August 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Fantasy Violence, Animated Blood
Powered by

Procedural, unrestricted exploration is the essence of No Man's Sky , but thanks to years of massive content updates, the game is so much more than that today. Just like with Minecraft , players can't really “beat” No Man's Sky , as it is created to be experienced endlessly, unless they choose to play in permadeath mode.

Thriving and brimming with possibilities, packed with crafting and building mechanics, as well as dozens of freeform activities, this shared universe operates on an entirely different scale compared to other open-world games. Even players who want a more focused experience are now in luck, as later updates added story missions known as expeditions, and even an intelligent robotic race to the No Man's Sky universe.

item.title: Best Horror Walking Simulator Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Horror walking simulators focus on psychological trauma, not monsters or combat.
  • These games explore deep fears through subtle storytelling and eerie atmospheres.
  • The scariest part is the slow, quiet unraveling of safety in familiar spaces.

There’s a special kind of fear that comes from simply walking. No guns, no combat — not even a sprint button to save you. Just you, your thoughts, and whatever that sound was behind the door you just closed. Horror walking simulators don’t hide behind jump scares or boss fights. They take the slow route, winding players through dark hallways, crumbling memories, and stories that feel a little too real.

These games don’t ask players to fight monsters. They are the monsters. And whether it’s psychological trauma or something a little more... squishy, these horror walking sims show that the scariest thing in a game might just be walking forward.

The Town of Light

The Hospital May Not Take Responsibility for What You See

  • Release Date : February 26, 2016
  • Developer : LKA
  • Publisher : Wired Productions

Set inside the ruins of a real psychiatric hospital in Volterra, Italy, The Town of Light threads its horror through grounded realism. Players step into the role of Renee, a former patient returning years later to piece together her fragmented memories. But this isn’t a story about hauntings or apparitions. It's about the way trauma lingers in peeling wallpaper and echoing hallways. There are no enemies to fight, but there's plenty to fear, especially when Renee’s internal voice begins to diverge from the documents and facts scattered across the hospital.

There’s something deeply unsettling about how the game blends historical records of psychiatric abuse with surreal, hand-drawn dream sequences. It doesn’t just ask players to observe Renee’s past; it forces them to question what they’re seeing and why it matters. And while it never throws a monster at the screen, the weight of knowing these events could’ve happened, or did, makes every quiet step hit harder than any scream ever could.

Infliction

Poltergeists Hate Mirrors for a Reason

Infliction
Adventure
Horror
Systems
Released
October 18, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Xbox One, PS5, Switch, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Infliction is what happens when a domestic setting turns hostile. Players are dropped into an abandoned suburban home shortly after a tragedy, left to uncover the story by digging through letters, voice recordings, and haunted objects. At first, it’s just tension. Doors close on their own. Lights flicker. But then the house starts remembering, and players are forced to relive increasingly disturbing moments tied to grief, abuse, and guilt. It’s not subtle, but it doesn’t want to be.

While technically there’s a hostile presence, most of the time, Infliction feels like walking through the aftermath of something terrible. It leans into the same kind of personal, psychological horror that P.T. made famous, but keeps it grounded in familial spaces — nurseries, kitchens, and bedrooms. Places that were once safe. And that slow, quiet unraveling of safety is what gives Infliction its staying power, long after the credits roll.

Visage

Nobody Smiles in the House, Not Even the Walls

Visage
Horror
Systems
Released
October 30, 2020
ESRB
m
Developer(s)
SadSquare Studio

Publisher(s)
SadSquare Studio
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

At a glance, Visage looks like another P.T. -inspired indie horror. But it doesn’t take long for that comparison to wear thin. It’s slower, meaner, and far more committed to breaking players down across its non-linear chapters. Each one introduces a different tragic figure haunting the house, and none of them play fair. There are no weapons, only hiding spots and darkness, and the latter becomes a real threat thanks to the sanity mechanic, which punishes players for staying in the dark too long.

What makes Visage truly terrifying is how little it cares about giving players control. Objects move when they shouldn’t. Hallways shift behind closed doors. And sometimes, the worst thing a player can do is turn around. It’s one of the rare walking sims that doesn't just build atmosphere but maintains it like a noose, tightening with every step. Few horror games feel this suffocating, and somehow, that’s exactly what makes it impossible to stop playing.

Madison

The Camera Flash is Louder Than the Screams

MADiSON
Puzzle
Indie Games
Adventure
Action
Simulation
Systems
Released
July 8, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL
7 /10

Developer(s)
BLOODIOUS GAMES
Publisher(s)
BLOODIOUS GAMES, Perpetual Europe
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Nintendo Switch, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows, Xbox Series X/S
Powered by

Sometimes, the scariest thing in a horror game isn’t the monster but the idea that players might have to look at it. Madison understands that better than most. It turns a Polaroid camera into both a mechanic and a psychological trap, forcing players to snap photos of things they really don’t want to see. It’s all tied into a twisted story about demonic rituals, family trauma, and a possessed boy named Luca who gets stuck reliving a past that refuses to stay buried.

What makes Madison terrifying is how intimate it feels. Players aren’t exploring some sprawling haunted mansion; they’re just trying to escape their childhood home, and that setting only makes the tension more suffocating. Every hallway looks familiar but feels wrong. Every room tells a story that gets darker the longer players linger. And the camera, which develops photos in real time, is more of a curse than a tool. Nothing about the experience relies on jump scares or chase sequences. It’s a horror game that only asks players to walk and look, but it still ends up making them want to shut their eyes.

Blair Witch

Lost in the Woods, and Somehow Worse When Found

Blair Witch
7 /10
9.0 /10
Released
August 30, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
Bloober Team
Publisher(s)
Lionsgate Games
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC, Amazon Luna
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

The real trick with Blair Witch isn’t what players see but what they can’t. Set in the Black Hills Forest in 1996, it drops a former cop named Ellis into a missing child case that spirals straight into supernatural terror. It borrows just enough from the movie to feel connected, but it builds its own mythology around the Blair Witch without relying on found footage gimmicks. There are no weapons, just a flashlight, a camcorder, and a dog named Bullet who honestly deserves a medal for bravery.

What makes Blair Witch shine as a walking simulator is how it messes with space and time. The forest shifts behind players when they’re not looking, paths lead back to where they started, and reality starts to fray the deeper Ellis walks into the woods. Most of the scares come from atmosphere: radio static, whispers in the trees, and VHS tapes that change the world when played back. And the ending isn’t based on survival but on how players treat their dog and manage their guilt. It’s a game that punishes carelessness, not with a death screen, but with an ending that feels disturbingly personal.

SOMA (Safe Mode)

Under the Ocean, No One Can Hear Your Existential Crisis

SOMA
8 /10
9.8 /10
Released
September 15, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
Frictional Games
Publisher(s)
Frictional Games
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Frictional’s SOMA originally featured deadly monsters stalking its underwater research stations, but with the addition of Safe Mode, it turned into something far more focused and arguably more powerful. Without the need to hide or run, players are left with nothing between them and the philosophical nightmare at the heart of the game. Consciousness, identity, the soul — it all gets cracked open and studied under flickering fluorescent lights.

What really sticks with players isn’t the horror of the creatures, but the horror of their implications. The people who used to live in this station aren’t just gone; they were copied, backed up, and overwritten like files on a hard drive. Every button press, every computer login, feels like intruding on someone else’s final thoughts. The water pressure might not crush players, but the story probably will.

Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs

The Pig Mask Never Leaves You

6 Images
6 Images
Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs
Horror
Systems
Released
September 10, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
8 /10

Developer(s)
The Chinese Room
Publisher(s)
Frictional Games
Platform(s)
PC, Nintendo Switch, PS4, Xbox One
Powered by

This isn’t The Dark Descent . There are no oil lanterns to refill or sanity meters to babysit. A Machine for Pigs instead pushes its horror through ideas and allegory, spinning a tale about a grieving father and the monstrous vision he builds to reshape the world. The pigmen themselves, with their human screams and jerky movements, are unnerving, but the real discomfort comes from the slow realization that Mandus may be the worst monster of all.

Players walk through slaughterhouses, factories, and catacombs, unraveling a descent that feels more philosophical than physical. There’s no combat, barely any puzzles, and yet it manages to disturb on a deeply cerebral level. It’s less about surviving and more about enduring, and in this story, sometimes walking forward is the bravest thing a person can do.

Layers of Fear (2016)

The Paint Drips Even When You Look Away

Layers of Fear
Horror
Systems
Released
February 16, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
7 /10

Developer(s)
Bloober Team
Publisher(s)
Aspyr
Platform(s)
Switch, PlayStation (Original), Xbox One, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Layers of Fear plays like a haunted house ride designed by a mad artist, and that’s because it kind of is. Players take on the role of a tormented painter returning to his mansion to complete his “masterpiece,” but the house refuses to stay still. Hallways twist behind closed doors. Rooms melt. Paintings warp and whisper. And somewhere inside all that madness is a truth he refuses to face.

What makes this walking sim different is how aggressively it manipulates space. Players can walk through a door, turn around, and find the room has vanished behind them. It weaponizes perspective, trust, and routine. And because everything is tied to the painter’s unraveling mind, every brushstroke feels like a confession. It’s not scary because it wants to be. It’s scary because it has no control over itself, and neither does the player.
